name: What happens when you enter a website in a browser
description: This diagram demonstrates what happens when you open a website in your browser. All elements are interactive. Try to click on any of them. For instance you can start with the address bar in the browser icon.

body.text:
if domain is not present in the hosts file it will make a DNS request via a specified nameserver.

But before sending a DNS packet to a nameserver. It should first find which device to send it. For this it needs to perform ARP lookup.

childItems.name: gethostbyname
childItems.description: gethostbyname is a system call that resolves specified host name or domain name to an IP address. It first checks if there is an entry in the /etc/hosts file for a specified host name. If not, it will proceed with DNS protocol which is configured in /etc/resolv.conf

body.text: If domain is not present in cache, it then calls gethostbyname

childItems.name: Hosts file
childItems.description:
As your machine gets started, it will need to know the mapping of some hostnames to IP addresses before DNS can be referenced. On Linux this mapping is kept in the /etc/hosts file. In the absence of a name server, any network program on your system consults this file to determine the IP address that corresponds to a host name.

Here is an example of how it looks like:

127.0.0.1       localhost   deep.openna.com
208.164.186.1   deep.openna.com  deep
208.164.186.2   mail.openna.com  mail
208.164.186.3   web.openna.com  web

body.text: it first checks if domain is present in the hosts file
Once it knows a device that is behind the nameserver IP it will send a DNS query to find the address for the domain name that a user has entered in a browser

TCP packets have to travel through numerous hops to get from a laptop all the way to a server. A server can be physically located in another country or another continent. To get to the server TCP packets have to navigate through various so-called "Autonomous Systems" with a help of Border Gateway Protocol. Click BGP to get more information
What happens when you open a website in your browser?

This is an interactive diagram that demonstrates you what happens behind the scenes when you open a website. All elements in this diagram are clickable. To simplify the diagram we presume that everything runs on Linux
Once a socket is created a client establishes a TCP connection to the server
After TCP connection is established, the client performs a so called "TLS handshake" to kickstart encrypted communication session
After TLS session is established a client sends HTTPS request to the server

An ARP lookup is needed in order to identify the MAC address of the machine that has a specific IP address. If ARP table does not have an entry for an IP address in question, it will perform ARP lookup
